description.text:
Add some spinny death to your SM transports with this conversion kit.

Currently includes a twin linked assault cannon, top plate mount and a hopefully snug fit mount that should still allow 360 rotation of the turret without gluing anything.

Update
Added in two variations of the assault cannon turret. One with a flat mount in case you just want to blue tack it onto your existing transport and new version with a larger and more detailed mount that may fit better (yet to be tested)

Note that this is a remix of others work. Thank you for those that supplied parts.
The top plate was resized to fit on a standard SM transport tank.

Also working on a variant based on the version available from FW.

description.text:
Many thanks to NickRimmer for the original design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1930233. I really liked the fan duct setup, but wanted to be able to view the nozzle during a print.

I modified the duct to be one piece instead of three in the original design, then made a cut out to allow me to see the print nozzle. While I was modifying, I added holes for 5mm LEDs to be mounted on the interior of the duct that provide direct illumination of the print nozzle and print bed.

I printed the duct using PETG with supports from the bed only. After printing, I added LEDs from this source: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01BV2OTLG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

description.text:
Geometry completely redesigned to accommodate the latest Leatherman Surge utilizing effortless retention. The tool slips in under its own weight and is held in place fairly securely. Can be pulled out quickly and easily by pulling it up through the finger slot. Makes a nice audible click when it goes in. I have included 3 variations:

  1. Surge Holster for a 1.75" wide riggers belt.
  2. Surge Holster for a 1.75" wide riggers belt with Anker LC40 flashlight holder
  3. Surge Holster for regular belt.

Should be printed vertically. You can print just up to the detent catches to check fitment and see if you need to enlarge. That's about 1.8 inches up from the bottom.

remixed_from.title: Geeetech Rostock Delta Led strip clip

description.text:
I downloaded the Geetech Rostock Delta LED strip clip by Quadsequence, as it looked like it would fit my Jaycar TL4100 (TL-4100) delta I bought a few weeks back, so i promptly printed it out. Unfortunately the pillar supports by Geetech are quite a lot larger, so I downloaded the STL and imported them into Tinkercad for editing. I filled the holes, made the arms shorter, made the overall width shallower to fit my ebay LED strip that I have laying around, and popped in some 7.8mm holes to make it a nice tight fit on the 8mm poles.

I tried affixing the LED strips to the PLA mounts, but the cheap adhesive kept coming off. I next tried some superglue, but managed to get my fingers stuck to everything :). So, the LED's eventually were stuck to the clips with 4 cable ties, between the gap of the LED's. I wired it underneath to the 12V input source of the duinotech board. It does get a bit "pulsy" when the heater bed is keeping the temp right, so I may filter the strips with a capacitor yet.

It definitely helps to view the build in progress, and shows up any irregularities (like the copious amounts of glue on my bed!) You won't need the one at the back shining into your eyes either.

Edit: I will probably shorten the arms further yet, as I was printing a large model today (150mm dia), and the print platform (motor) kept clashing with the lights. I had to unclip them for that print, but can definitely lose 1cm more yet.
Til strøbyskolen

print_settings.Notes:: Note:

title: TEVO Little Monster Bed Heater Wiring Connector Enclosure

description.text:
This box and accessories cleans up the bed heater and thermistor wiring mess in the back, secures the wires through the top plate and hides them out of sight in the column v-groove.

Fits over the connectors for the bed heater wires with outlet for the wires placed in the v-groove of the Z column.

I fit the heater and thermistor wiring into one v-groove directed through the notch in the top plate with a short piece of spare harness tube included in the TEVO kit.

Printer:

TEVO Little Monster

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm layer height

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The print settings are as follows for each model with required quantity shown in parentheses:

  • Bed Heater Connector Box (1x)
    • 0.3 mm layer height
    • 25% infill
    • support required
    • no raft
  • Mini-Plate (2x)
    • 0.3 mm layer height
    • 25% infill
    • no support
    • no raft
  • V-Groove Fasteners (4x)
    • 0.2 mm layer height
    • 50% infill
    • no support
    • raft required

Note: These fasteners are generally useful for mounting to the TEVO Little Monster printer frame so I printed two sets of 12 and brake them off the raft when I need them.

Work-in the V-Groove Fasteners

Prepare the v-groove fasteners by removing them from the raft and attaching the mini holding plate to the column.

The fasteners are inserted with the top arms in the vertical position and fastened by turning them 90 degrees into a horizontal position.

You may need to use pliers to turn them for the first time. After that they can be fastened by hand.

Installing the Connector Box

The hardest part of the installation is getting the c-channel profile to fit into the v-groove with all the wires inside. After some fiddling I found the following approach to be the easiest:

  1. Cut the c-channel so its length allows for a 5 cm (2 in) gap at the bottom and a 4 cm (1.5 in) gap at the top of the channel.

  2. Cut about 5 cm (2 in) wiring harness tube and place it over the ends of the heater wires and thermistor cable at the top plate end.

  3. Fit the two heater heater wires into the plastic c-channel profile by pressing them into the profile so they are flat at the back and not twisted. They will be held firmly in place.

  4. Starting at the bottom, a little above where the top edge of the connector box plate will end, place the thermistor cable in the v-groove and place the c-channel over it. Direct the thermistor cable to be between the two heater wires and the c-channel will fit into the v-groove.

  5. At this point the c-channel profile will pop out with little effort so you use the mini-plate and v-groove faster to clamp it in place.

  6. Tape the top of the c-channel and wires temporarily at the top to hold it in place.

  7. Fit the c-channel profile from the mini-plate down by centering the thermistor cable as you press in the c-channel profile (with the heater wires in it) into the v-groove. Tape the bottom of the c-channel profile to the c-column to hold it in place.

  8. Place the connector box by guiding the wires from the bed heater into the bottom notch over the connectors, with the back slot over the v-groove where the wires go into the v-groove. Use the two printed v-groove fasteners to secure it by inserting the fasteners into the holes and turning them 90 degrees.

  9. Remove the tape at the top of the column (from step 6.)

  10. Proceed to place the c-channel profile with the wires to the top of the column by centering the thermistor cable between the heater wires in the c-channel profile as you press the profile into the v-groove. You must secure the c-channel in place by pressing on it with your thumb or it will pop out of place. As you work your way up, you should move the mini-holding plate higher to clamp the profile closer to where you are working to prevent the already inserted c-channel profile from popping out.

  11. When have inserted top end of the c-channel into the v-groove, fix it into place with the mini-holding plate.

  12. Double check that the c-channel is not sticking over the edge of the column. If the thermistor cable is not centered between the heater wires in the c-channel profile then one edge of the c-channel will stick out over the column edge. You will need to place the mini-plate below the problem area and restart the process from this point at step 10. Don't be discouraged. I went at it for about 20 minutes before I figured out how to do it.

  13. Place the wiring harness tube into the notch in the top plate so that about 2 cm (1 in.) stick out below the top plate and the rest above.

  14. Secure the tube by securing a mini-plate onto the back of the column with the mini-plate sticking out over the harness tube and preventing it from coming out of the notch.

I am new to 3D printing and find Fusion 360 to be the easiest to use when taking an idea to a working model.

I use parameterized dimensions to allow easy tweaking and reducing the model size for faster test prints.

description.text:
Micromake C1 COREXZ

These are all the parts you need to convert your Micromake C1 to the COREXZ system. This conversion eliminates the racking motion of the X-axis inherent to the H-Bot system.
As a result you will get true circles and not elliptical circles :) Top and bottom layers will also be nicely closed, no more annoying space between the filament lines. Please note that the effector is designed for a MGN9H linear rail (310mm).

Make sure you read the firmware notes below before doing this conversion, there are some cables you need to switch!

Firmware notes:

NOTICE!

This firmware is intended for the Micromake C1 COREXZ conversion. It will
not work correctly with a stock Micromake C1!

For this firmware to work correctly with your converted Micromake C1,
please switch the X and Z stepper motor cables on your main board. The
original X motor plug needs to go into the Z motor socket. Subsequently
the orgininal Z motor plug needs to go into the X motor socket.

This firmware uses 64 step resolution. You need to switch your main board
resolution by removing the MS-1 jumper from the main board. The included
image shows you where to find the MS-1 jumper.

After the above steps, upload this firmware to your board and you are done.

Printer:

Micromake C1

Yes

title: Angle bracket / front and back panel support for Anet A8

description.text:
My first "invention" here on Thingiverse. This is just a simple angle bracket that I use to strengthen the front panel of my Anet A8 (stupidly, the roller for the Y-axis belt is attached to it). I have seen better solutions on here, but my hack seems to do the job for now in stabilising the panel and it's already giving me better prints. I may still upgrade to one of the properly engineered solutions in time.

Brackets were screwed to a piece of 8mm MDF with some 3x13mm wood screws.

I made a separate bracket to support the Y-axis stepper motor.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in colourless PLA. I made four, with two of them mirrored from the original (see pictures). They came out nice and rigid, no further work needed.

This was an exercise in design with FreeCAD for me. I'm including the file. The bracket is simply a union of a cylinder, some cubes/cuboids and a padded polygon, with a couple more cylinders subtracted from the part as screw holes. Plus I countersunk the small screw holes a bit for good measure (after I discovered on the first piece I made that you can't very well do it with a drill, ahem).

title: DIY Laser engraver withe 3D printed parts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Please see my instructable for a complete build description at:

https://www.instructables.com/id/DIY-3D-Printed-Laser-Engraver-With-Approx-38x29cm-

To see this thing work visit:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jCnYnqfBID8&t=1s

Printer:

Da Vinci pro 1.0 3in1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

80% (and 100%, see text)

Notes:

Printer settings PLA:

210 degrees C
no heated bed
0.25 mm layers
shell thickness (normal, top and bottom surface) 4 layers
80% infill (except the "belt holder plates" print those with 100% infill)
all speeds at 30 mm/s (except non printing and retraction speed at 60mm/s and the bottom layer at 20 mm/s)
brim 5 mm
no supports
extrusion ratio 100%

Printer settings ABS:
normal ABS settings with 100% infill
Post-printing: remove the brim and dril out the holes at the desired size (see the instructable)

Yet an other laser engraver?...

...sure it is! But I know how important it is to get your information from differend designs and angles of perspective, and so the things I show you, others mayby don't, and vice versa. Therefore I hope that with this project, along with all the others, I can make a contribution to your knowledge of laser engravers and inspires you to build one yourself.

I have made two engravers prior to this one: a "pocket laser engraver" made of 2 DVD players and a little laser (300mW or so) and a "quick, cheap and dirty laser engraver"' made of a scrap printer and a scrap flat bed scanner and a stronger laser (2W).

Now I own a 3D printer I decided to make a nicer one who is bigger (38x29 cm work area), accurate and has no play between the parts. And I think I succeeded in that.

title: TEVO Wiring Harness Top Plate Clamp

description.text:
This clamps the umbilical wiring harness going to the effector to the top plate from the bottom and top of the plate fixing in place and directing the harness between the X and Z columns out the way of anything it could snag.

The clamp is designed to be put in place (or removed) with all the wiring already in place, so there is no need to disconnect it from the extruder.

Printer:

TEVO Little Monster

Resolution:

0.25 mm layer height

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed mine with ABS but see no reason why this would not work in PLA.

Print settings

  • 0.25 mm layer height
  • 25% infill
  • no support (support is already part of the model)
  • no raft

Installation

Remove the support in the top ring clamp inverted U-slot before assembling.

  1. Insert the the clamp tube through the hole of the top plate from below with the umbilical in the long slot below the top plate and in the short slot above the top plate. Orient the umbilical to point between the X and Z columns.

  2. Place the ring clamp over the clamp tube with the slot over the umbilical so it clamps it above the top plate.

  3. Screw on the 3D printed nut to hold everything firmly in place.
Using the Filament Guide

The tube also includes a small clamp for the PTFE tube to guide the filament through the top plate and prevent it from going back and potentially looping over and around the spool.

To use it:

  1. Cut off about 8 cm (3 in.) of PTFE tube

  2. Insert the filament into the PTFE tube

  3. Press fit the PTFE tube into the little clamp. Make sure the bottom of the PTFE tube is 5 mm (0.25 in.) above the bottom of the clamp because there is a small ledge at the bottom of the clamp to keep the PTFE tube from falling through the bottom.

description.text:
Absolutely love logansgraphicd's case, but I have a multi pet home and all those slits and holes are just begging to suck in pet hair, so set about modifying the design just slightly.

  • Front Bottom: Cut away part of the front to form a recessed area above the fan grill, to which can be fitted an 80mm fan filter.
  • Front Top: relocated and resized power button hole to fit a 20mm round switch. Added a 2nd hole, 13.2mm x 20mm for my hotend LED switch.
  • Right Panel 1: Removed slits.
  • Right Panel 2: Removed slits, added backing to Tevo emblem so it is no longer a hole to the interior of the case.
  • Left Panel 1: Added caps to the circular holes that can be cutout as needed to run cables into the case.
  • Left Panel 2 /w SD: Added backing to Tevo emblem so it is no longer a hole to the interior of the case.
  • Rear Panel: Removed slits.

No changes made to Top or Bottom, see logangraphicd's original design for these STLs.

Also included 2 items I created to complement the case:

  • #6 screw cap: Friction fit screw cover for Philips flat heat 6-32 3/4" bolts.
  • Tevo case LCD bezel: Bezel to be glued to Front top, adding a more finished look to the LCD.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Support not needed for any parts EXCEPT for Front Bottom, will require support due to recessed area.

print_settings.Notes:: 0.2 mm layer height

description.text:
A ruler designed to mark the filament at 15 cm before feeding and reading off the actual length fed afterwards.

The filament snaps into the bottom and top of the ruler and fits into the grove to make reading off the length easier.

The length of the ruler is 15 cm with a ledge at the top that can be used as a guide for a sharp razor mark or marker line.

The markings on the ruler are in mm of actual fed filament to be read off where the mark lines up after feeding 10 cm of filament through the extruder.

Printer:

TEVO Little Monster

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

30%, not critical

Notes:

I printed mine with ABS but see no reason why this would not work in PLA.

Print settings

  • 0.2 mm layer height
  • 30% infill, not critical
  • no support, already included in the model
  • raft does not matter
You need to clip off the tiny support holding the end of the clamp at the bottom of the ruler.

After realizing that the extruder feed accuracy needs to be tested for new filaments I decided to make a ruler designed for the task that allows easy marking and measuring of the extruder filament feed length and does not require three hands to hold the filament in place.

I am new to 3D printing and find Fusion 360 to be the easiest to use when taking an idea to a working model.

I use parameterized dimensions to allow easy tweaking and reducing the model size for faster test prints.

Marking 15 cm before filament feed

Snap the filament into the top and bottom clamps of the ruler and press into the grove along the scale.

With the bottom of the ruler resting on the extruder intake mark off 15 cm using the top of the ruler as a guide. Only the bottom of the mark is relevant so don't worry about how thin it is.

Reading actual feed length

After feeding 10 cm of the filament with:

G92 E0; reset extruder origin
G1 E100 F120; feed 10 cm of filament at 120 mm/min (adjust this to your usual feed rate
G92 E0; reset extruder origin

Read off the actual length from the bottom of the mark aligning with scale printed on the ruler. Numbers are in mm of actual feed. In the image, I adjusted my extruder steps/mm to compensate for always underfeeding by 5mm on 100mm feed so it is showing 100mm.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.
This is a six part set of vented ear caps for a Mandalorian helmet. You can scale them to fit any helmet, keep in mind that resizing may need to be tweeked since it will distort connecting parts. These Ear Caps are designed to be used with my Mandalorian Range Finder Stalk. There are four small ear cap tops. These parts are designed to be placed on helmet in layers. The part with one hole and no detail is the base layer to be cut and used to fill gap between the helmet and the next part above the helmet band line. The next part is the base that is mounted directly to the helmet, you will know this part because it has a raised line along the bottom, a hole and curve cutout in the center and two small recessed holes for rare earth magnets. Once this part is mounted, you add the range finder stalk then the next part it the small part with the rectangle hole along the bottom that fits over the previous part. Lastly , the final cover that has some detailing on it. Sand and paint as you like, Thanks and enjoy.

Scale 1/1
For optimum printing, use supports under the workpiece
Enjoy !!!

This thing was made with Tinkercad.
This is a six part set of ear caps for a Mandalorian helmet. You can scale them to fit any helmet, keep in mind that resizing may need to be tweeked since it will distort connecting parts. These Ear Caps are designed to be used with my Mandalorian Range Finder Stalk. There are four small ear cap tops. These parts are designed to be placed on helmet in layers. The part with one hole and no detail is the base layer to be cut and used to fill gap between the helmet and the next part above the helmet band line. The next part is the base that is mounted directly to the helmet, you will know this part because it has a raised line along the bottom, a hole and curve cutout in the center and two small recessed holes for rare earth magnets. Once this part is mounted, you add the range finder stalk then the next part it the small part with the rectangle hole along the bottom that fits over the previous part. Lastly , the final cover that has some detailing on it. Sand and paint as you like, Thanks and enjoy.

title: Mini LED Dimmer Case, Anet A8 and AM8 Mountable

description.text:
NOTE: This thing is meant as a replacement case for the following Chinese LED dimmer: DC 12V 8A Light Dimmer Brightness Control For Single Color LED Strip ED. There are many similar ones on eBay and it probably doesn't matter which one you get, provided it has the same design.

So, one day I decided to open one of these cheap Chinese LED dimmers from eBay, and I was shocked to find it being almost completely empty with tons of wasted space. To combat this, I designed this compact case which acts as a replacement.

Features

  • Very compact design, reducing the size of the original case by a huge amount.
  • Simple assembly, requiring only buying three extra screws and reusing other screws from the original dimmer.
  • Comes with three different bottom parts: A normal one, one with a mount for the Anet A8 printer, and one which can be mounted on the AM8 frame using 2 regular M5*10 screws.

Assembly

  • Disassemble the original LED dimmer and salvage all the parts, you won't need the four larger screws and the original case.
  • Print the Mini LED Dimmer Case. You will need the top and bottom parts. For the bottom, you can choose the normal version, the one which mounts on the Anet A8 printer, or one which can be mounted on the AM8 frame. By default, the Anet A8 version mounts on the right side, but you may mirror the model in your slicer if you wish to print it on the left side. The AM8 version can be mounted anywhere on the AM8 frame.
  • Insert the PCB into the bottom part and secure it using the two tiny screws from the original dimmer.
  • Insert the potentiometer into the top part and secure it using the original nut. The top part has small nubs on the inside which will hold it in place while you tighten the nut.
  • Press the two parts against each other and use three M3x18 screws with smaller heads (pictured on the thing's upload) to fasten them together. I used extra screws from my Anet A8 printer.
  • If you were printing the Anet A8 mount version, remove the screws on the top right of the printer's frame and install the dimmer using them.
  • If you were printing the AM8 mount version, mount it on the frame using 2 M5*10 screws.
  • Wire the dimmer exactly the same like the original. Last image on this thing is here as a reference.

I have also included the Blender files in case you want to edit it further.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

30%

description.text:
This is a replacement arm for the Zerotech Dobby. Although it is printed in PLA here I think that something stronger and with a higher glass temperature would be better, maybe something like polycarbonate which I have not tried.

The channel down the middle is intended for the motor wires such that, once this arm has been installed, if it needs replacing it can be removed without desoldering the motor wires. It might be best to secure the wires in their channels using a drop of hot glue or something similar.

When replacing the arm much the best thing to do is to desolder the motor wires before doing anything else although, at a pinch, the arm can be replaced with the motor wires still attached.

To install the new arm do the following:-

  1. (Ideally) desolder the motor wires.
  2. Pop off the small cap on the underside of the old arm. This can be done by inserting a sharp blade between cap and arm.
  3. Peel off the thin plastic cover on the bottom of the arm. This will expose the channel in which the motor wires are secured.
  4. Pop out the arm (if it is still attached). The best way to do this is to open the arm and use the heel of your hand to exert some real force pushing up from under the motor.
  5. Remove the motor from the arm. If the wires are still soldered to the pcb you wioll need to cut away the motor pod and also part of the arm pivot so that the arm can be removed.
  6. Screw the motor to the replacement arm.
  7. run the wires through the channel and up through the pivot point
  8. Insert the new arm into the pivot hole.
  9. Resolder the motor wires if you had desoldered them.

PS - the front structure is nothing to do with this project, it was a (unsuccessful) attempt to eliminate jello.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Ultimaker 2

No

No

25%

title: Makerbot Style RepRap Extruder Carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This part will allow you to mount non-standard extruders to a RepRap Mendel.  The pictures show an MBE-v9 by QU-BD but the goal of this part is to enable the mounting of any Makerbot style extruder.  You can mount any Thing-O-Matic or Cupcake extruder, the most practical options being a Plastruder mk7, Frostruder v2, or Unicorn.  
Makerbot's open source toolheads are really sweet (and I have a bunch of them) so I decided to try some of them on a Mendel.  Now, so can you!

BOM:
4xLM8UU bearings
10 M3-20 OR 10 #4-40x3/4 countersunk machine screws
10 M3 OR #4-40 nuts (whichever you choose, make sure they match the bolts) Makerbot extruders are bolted in with 2 M4 bolts, but I kept them off the BOM because I see them as more of an extruder part. If you have a QU-BD extruder, the version 2 files will work fine. Depending on your extruder you may need to move the centre holes. This can be easily accomplished in Blender. I printed the rails out and then used the physical part to determine where the holes need to be. You could also drill the holes if you want. I included version 1 options which have different hole positions as well. Anyway, print two belt grips and a matching set of left and right rides. Assembly is pretty self explanatory.

comments.text: Here is the number one question that I cant find ANYWHERE. I have a Prusa i3. I don't like the dual extruders hanging off the SIDE of 2 bars. I would rather have the extruders above like my FFCP and Makerbots. I see you have that setup, however the parts I need are the X motor and X idler. I would much rather have the 2 bearings/smooth rods side by side instead of above one another.
comments.author: agilliam

comments.text: I am always seeking for a way to make my Mendel dual extruding. I just said that why not use makerbot style extruder on Mendels! Then I found this. Thank you!

author: cloudykoe99

description.text:
I have a leather jacket which doesn't even have zipper ventilation but I decided to be cool about it and I made this system. I used the same printed parts to draw and cut the jacket. It can be mounted anywhere on the jacket but check if it doesn't bother you before. It takes M3 screws of about 10mm in length. The holes and the lift it has underneath is supposed to push the air throughout the jacket. You could glue a piece of sponge on the inside of the top part to avoid high speeding bugs entering and eventually leave bruises.

Update: I added a new version with a better design both for looks as for the airflow. Should be placed on each side so the air goes towards your arms. Going from higher to lower volume will increase air speed, drop the pressure and get a more refreshing feeling. I applied the same principle as for the one for the back of the jacked (see my other design).

Be cool and ride safe!

description.text:
A simple direct-contact water block, with 1/4" hose barbs, originally designed for "60w" thermoelectric coolers.

This device puts the water in direct contact with the object to be cooled, so don't use it for CPUs or really anything valuable.

Requires a seal - I designed the gland to fit a 218 silicone O-ring (McMaster-Carr #1283N91); it seals really well that way. However, you could just cut a seal out of neoprene or something, or use gasket maker to seal it up.

FreeCAD design's included.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.
This is a six part set of Boba Fett ear caps for a Mandalorian helmet. You can scale them to fit any helmet, keep in mind that resizing may need to be tweeked since it will distort connecting parts. These Ear Caps are designed to be used with my Mandalorian Range Finder Stalk. There are four small ear cap tops. These parts are designed to be placed on helmet in layers. The part with one hole and no detail is the base layer to be cut and used to fill gap between the helmet and the next part above the helmet band line. The next part is the base that is mounted directly to the helmet, you will know this part because it has a raised line along the bottom, a hole and curve cutout in the center and two small recessed holes for rare earth magnets. Once this part is mounted, you add the range finder stalk then the next part it the small part with the rectangle hole along the bottom that fits over the previous part. Lastly, the final cover that has some detailing on it. Sand and paint as you like, Thanks and enjoy.

title: Improved Adaptive Gripping Box for Raptor Reloaded Hand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Developers at MIT have developed an updated gripper box for use with the Raptor Reloaded and Phoenix hands that allows for adaptive grip. This design is fully compatible with the standard gripper box and makes several improvements over the previously released whippletree gripper box, including:

  • Inclusion of the thumb in the adaptive grip
  • Balancing of forces
  • Improvement of assembly process

We think that this design is even easier to assemble than the standard gripper box, and greatly improves functionality. Hoping for your feedback!

Note: we have only tested its compatibility with the Raptor Reloaded, but expect it to work with the Phoenix Hand as well.

Both STLs and SLDPRTs have been included for maximum utility. An assembly guide is included for ease of use. The prints vary slightly between the right and left hand, so note which files you need prior to printing!

Please let us know how it performs, and especially with an end-user!

This work was supported through a Technology Office grant at MIT Lincoln Laboratory.

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad.
This is a six part set of Ventilated ear caps for a Mandalorian helmet. You can scale them to fit any helmet, keep in mind that resizing may need to be tweaked since it will distort connecting parts. These Ear Caps are designed to be used with my Mandalorian Range Finder Stalk. There are four small ear cap tops. These parts are designed to be placed on helmet in layers. The part with one hole and no detail is the base layer to be cut and used to fill gap between the helmet and the next part above the helmet band line. The next part is the base that is mounted directly to the helmet, you will know this part because it has a raised line along the bottom, a hole and curve cutout in the center and two small recessed holes for rare earth magnets. Once this part is mounted, you add the range finder stalk then the next part it the small part with the rectangle hole along the bottom that fits over the previous part. Lastly, the final cover that has some detailing on it. Sand and paint as you like, Thanks and enjoy.

author: urmeltom

print_settings.Notes:: Note:

title: TEVO Little Monster End Stop Guards

description.text:
The guards protect the end stop sensors and keep the wiring harness umbilical or the filament from getting squeezed between the top plate and one of the carriages.

These mount securely with 4 v-groove fasteners into the column's side grooves. Twisting the fastener 90 by degrees secures it or removes it.

I had two mishaps that these guards would have prevented:

  1. The PTFE tube over the filament extruder was too long and it got caught between the top plate and one of the carriages as the printer was homing (at warp-9). This prevented the carriage from triggering the end stop sensor, causing the belts to grind as the control board was trying to bring the carriage home (from another galaxy, based on the amount of time it ran the motor.) Only powering down the printer stopped the insanity.

    This caused the belt to detach from the carriage, needing to take off the top plate to reattach.

  2. I made the mistake of homing the effector with the filament removed and the end of the filament just happened to get into one of the end stop sensors, triggering it. This made the controller think this axis was already home and tried to bring the other two into position.

    This effort caused the effector to move to its maximum offset and lock up the two carriages. The printer kept trying while making a horrible belt griding sound, terminated by powering down.

Printer:

TEVO Little Monster

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm layer height

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed mine with ABS but see no reason why this would not work in PLA.

The plates are designed to print flat to make layer adhesion not a factor when clamping these with the fasteners.

Print settings

The print settings are as follows for each model with required quantity shown in parentheses:

  • Guard Plates (3x)
    • 0.3 mm layer height
    • 25% infill
    • no support
    • no raft
  • V-Groove Fasteners (12x)
    • 0.2 mm layer height
    • 50% infill
    • no support
    • raft required

Note: These fasteners are generally useful for mounting to the TEVO Little Monster printer frame so I printed two sets of 12 and brake them off the raft when I need them.

Work-in the V-Groove Fasteners

Prepare the v-groove fasteners by removing them from the raft and attaching the mini holding plate to the column.

The fasteners are inserted with the top arms in the vertical position and fastened by turning them 90 degrees into a horizontal position.

You may need to use pliers to turn them for the first time. After that they can be fastened by hand.

Assembling the Guards

Important The side plates print opposite of how they assemble. The one on the left is the right plate and the one on the right is the left plate. In other words, the plate with the rectangular notch in the top edge goes on the side of the end stop sensor.

The horizontal bar is to be glued between the two side plates. I assembled these on the bottom plate upside down, clamped the horizontal bar between the two side plates and used a few tiny drops of MEK solvent to weld them in place. You can use any method to attach assemble the plates together.

Installing the Guards

Slide the guard over the column below the optical sensor and slide up to contact the top plate. Attach to the columns using 4 v-groove fasteners per column.

I am new to 3D printing and find Fusion 360 to be the easiest to use when taking an idea to a working model.

I use parameterized dimensions to allow easy tweaking and reducing the model size for faster test prints.

title: Wiring Schematic for Pigrrl Zero Plus, custom washer

description.text:
First off I wanted to again say thank you to Jpete24 for a fantastic project!
The .stl included with this thing is just a simple washer I used to help attach the screen. I used the #4-40 3/8" screws like from the original Pigrrl so these were helpful but that's not the main point of this thing. I mainly wanted to post this to provide a couple .jpgs with the schematic I drew up for myself to help me. I thought it could be useful to others. There are two versions so be careful. One is with the button pads the "correct" way and the other is if the button pads were flipped, which I accidentally had done. The GPIO pins for the Pi are in the correct orientation as per the video Jpete24 has up. Please let me know if you find any errors and I hope it helps some people!

description.text:
This is a remix of whittyman98's 3D Printed Magpul MOE Grip.

I used his base model, and added a bolt hole and nut location.

The original I printed slides up and down my airsoft picatinny rail, and needs a way to secure the grip to my rail. I added two bolt holes for a #10 bolt, and a indention to hold a #10 nut. This should keep the grip from sliding back and forth.

Dimensions for standard picatinny rails pulled from wikipedia. Rails may vary, depending on application/who made them.

Requires 2x #10-32 x 1.25" socket head cap screws, and 2x #10-32 nuts. Recommend threadlock as well. Bolts and nuts will not be flush with the flat surface, as there will be too little material remaining.

title: Mandalorian Gauntlet Right Top M3 Ver1

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad.
This the Right side Top Mandalorian Gauntlet that has been altered by me to change the configuration of April Storm’s Death Watch Mandalorian Gauntlets MARK3 (Male) with Integrated Hinge. I recommend that you download her Death Watch Mandalorian Gauntlets MARK3 (Male) with Integrated Hinge. Here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752380
You can use the bottom half of her model and this model to make your gauntlet and have a different look from the Death Watch type gauntlet.
Also I added the correctly sized mechanical key board key file to add to the gauntlet, see the pictures for example.
Per April,
The hinge has been designed to use a common bicycle spoke as the hinge pin. You can buy these from bike shops for $2 and cut to size. The model has been modified from the previous versions to be printed on larger format printers in one piece, there are also some minor changes to the model mostly to make it more durable
If you would like to watch a video on how to finish these once printed to MMCC standards go here: https://youtu.be/fusLep_OiKg
April also offers to print her gauntlets here: http://www.stormprops.com. This alteration has been made without the consent of April and I will not accept any profit or benefit for this alteration. I simply wish to share the alteration I performed to make my cos play more unique.

comments.text:
I just realized that I forgot to post the solution I came up with for the securing the gauntlets. I actually came up with this back in September 2017 and I posted it on RPF but not here. Basically, I did not have time to reprint and remake my gauntlets so this is an alteration that any of you can do.
First, you will need to order a set of long drill bits. I got my set from Amazon for about $10.00 and I used the drill bit that was slightly larger than the bicycle spoke I used for the hinge. I drilled a hole through the wall of the gauntlet upper half and along the length of the gauntlet. I placed this hole about 3/16” from the outer lip stopped before it came through the front end of the gauntlet. I then closed the gauntlet and drilled the hole through the lower half lining it up with the upper. Next I cut another bicycle spoke to fit and inserted it through the hole and presto it holds the gauntlet closed. I left a small part of the spoke exposed so that I could extract it with gloves on. I added pictures to show what I did.
comments.author: 11b30b4

comments.text: I'm new to 3d printing is there a way to mirror these (turn the right hand into left). I think the right hand gauntlet would make a great base for my computer hacking gauntlet idea but it needs to be on my left arm
comments.author: cmdrjpwalter

comments.text: cmdripwalter, Welcome to 3D printing. I am still just a novice myself but I can suggest a solution for you, I think... Ok so there are a ton of free 3D model software out there like blender. Basically, you can download the stl file I have here and through it into blender and mirror it. I am not sure it will line up perfectly with the lower half and until you print it, there is really no way to be sure. However, blender can be a bit intimidating if you are not familiar with it so an easier solution would be to use tinkercad. Tinkercad is a free online 3D modeling software you use through your browser and its very easy to learn. There is a mirror button on the top right side. So just create an account, upload the stl file, mirror it, then export it as an stl file.slice it and print it and you should be good to go.
comments.author: cmdrjpwalter

comments.text: Hello everyone, well I made these for DragonCon 2017 and after 2 days of putting them on and taking them off I have decided that I do not like the plastic clips that I had recommended using from April's original file. I am exploring other closing methods such as rare earth magnets, exterior clamps, and other possibilities. If you find a good method feel free to share it with everyone.

description.text:

title: SSD 2.5 to 3.5 Full adjusted for OEM

description.text: I really liked the original, used it quite a few times, but since I work on a lot of machines I found that the screw holes rarely lined up for more than 1, w/ an ssd that was fine, but not ideal. The sata ports were also closer to the center, which was a problem when upgrading an OEM computer. I moved the SSD screw holes farther to the correct side and expanded the model to line up with all 3 HDD holes, with the spare off center at the same distance for inverted positioning. Then I just removed triangles to minimize waste and decrease print time.

title: Mandalorian Gauntlet Left Top M3 Ver1

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad.
This the Left side Top Mandalorian Gauntlet that has been altered by me to change the configuration of April Storm’s Death Watch Mandalorian Gauntlets MARK3 (Male) with Integrated Hinge. I recommend that you download her Death Watch Mandalorian Gauntlets MARK3 (Male) with Integrated Hinge. Here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752380
You can use the bottom half of her model and this model to make your gauntlet and have a different look from the Death Watch type gauntlet. The large rectangle cutout on top is for the addition of a “hypnotic” LED bar kit that is available here:
http://www.goldmine-elec-products.com/prodinfo.asp?number=C6772
Per April,
The hinge has been designed to use a common bicycle spoke as the hinge pin. You can buy these from bike shops for $2 and cut to size. The model has been modified from the previous versions to be printed on larger format printers in one piece, there are also some minor changes to the model mostly to make it more durable
If you would like to watch a video on how to finish these once printed to MMCC standards go here: https://youtu.be/fusLep_OiKg
April also offers to print her gauntlets here: http://www.stormprops.com. This alteration has been made without the consent of April and I will not accept any profit or benefit for this alteration. I simply wish to share the alteration I performed to make my cos play more unique.

comments.text:
I just realized that I forgot to post the solution I came up with for the securing the gauntlets. I actually came up with this back in September 2017 and I posted it on RPF but not here. Basically, I did not have time to reprint and remake my gauntlets so this is an alteration that any of you can do.
First, you will need to order a set of long drill bits. I got my set from Amazon for about $10.00 and I used the drill bit that was slightly larger than the bicycle spoke I used for the hinge. I drilled a hole through the wall of the gauntlet upper half and along the length of the gauntlet. I placed this hole about 3/16” from the outer lip stopped before it came through the front end of the gauntlet. I then closed the gauntlet and drilled the hole through the lower half lining it up with the upper. Next I cut another bicycle spoke to fit and inserted it through the hole and presto it holds the gauntlet closed. I left a small part of the spoke exposed so that I could extract it with gloves on. I added pictures to show what I did.
comments.author: 11b30b4

comments.text: I love how simple yet amazing a quick LED can make everything more awesome.  I am glad I found this and will give it a test.  I am pushing the limits in time for holloween, but eh worth it in the end.  Thanks for the idea!
comments.author: mikelb0013

comments.text: Hello everyone, well I made these for DragonCon 2017 and after 2 days of putting them on and taking them off I have decided that I do not like the plastic clips that I had recommended using from April's original file. I am exploring other closing methods such as rare earth magnets, exterior clamps, and other possibilities. If you find a good method feel free to share it with everyone.
comments.author: 11b30b4

comments.text: I would suggest using 1" wide Rip-Tie velcro wire ties/organizers. They work perfectly for me. I am a LARPer though so my gauntlets have to stay on during some pretty hectic Nerf firefights. If I were just cosplaying then yes, I would use a drill press along the edges of the gauntlet that open and insert a ton of tiny cylinder rare earth magnets, but that can be a real pain in the ass to get all the poles facing in the right direction, friction fit them and superglued in to place unless you have some pretty nimble fingers and a chunk of time on your hands.

description.text: This is a box with a sliding lid. I use them to keep track of small parts like SD cards, guitar picks and the like. It prints easily and works great with very little "massaging" with a hobby knife. I like to print these with 100% infill though you can experiment. They require no support material but I do use a brim. I have only printed these in PLA but use your favorite material. If you open the stl file in a design program like Tinkercad, it's easy to put your own pattern on the lid. A pattern also makes a handy grip surface to open and close the box. These print great on my CR-10 with 200 degree (Celsius) nozzle and 60 degree bed. These boxes print quickly and don't require a lot of filament. I think they make great gifts or even "business cards" with the right design.

Assembly is simple. Just clean up the parts and glue them together. The board with holes glues into the top of the box to hold your epoxy tubes. The rods glue into the round indents on the front of the box to hang tape etc. The three prong peg board hanger glues into the rectangular indent on the back of the box. description.text:
My Oculus Play Area is a bit far from the walls so the tracking has always been good but not great while using wall mounts or placing the sensors on my coffee table. I decided to make extensions to get the sensors higher (and farther apart than the table allowed), using table clamps and selfie sticks.
The only thing that was missing was an adapter to attach the stick to the clamp.

I made versions of the adapter for the following angle: 0, 10, 20, 30 and 40. I only printed the 20-degree version but the other ones should work fine.
I also made a set of clips to tie the cable to the stick. The clips are not exactly the same size, there is one for each section of the selfie stick.

What I used:
Pack of 4 Table Mounting Clamp (USA, Canada)
3 Handheld Selfie Stick (USA, Canada)

I have an Xbox One elite controller and always use the paddle buttons on the bottom of the controller. But whenever I set the controller down on the couch the paddle buttons get pressed witch can sometimes cause problems with my game. I also use a Nyko Charge Base with my controllers. So I designed a new cover that would help stop the paddle buttons from being pressed accidentally and also accommodate the rechargeable battery.

It fits pretty well on the controller. There is some room for improvement to make it conform more to the controller but unless I get really picky I will probably just use the design as is. I’ve included 3 versions; the plane vanilla cover, the Nyko battery cover (needs some tweaks to make it fit in the charging doc), and my modified "Kickstand" cover.

This fits the Xbox one elite controller and will also fit the standard Xbone controller. You will have to clip off the right and left tabs on the bottom (leave the center tab) for the standard controller. Recommend printing it on its side.

This was my own design using the standard and Nyko battery covers as references for dimensions. Please feel free to share but not for commercial purposes.
Any comments or questions are welcome. Injoy!

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with PLA @ 190C. I would recommend to first print it at a very low speed 20%, and then if the top of the cooler got bent a little (since it has no support underneath and lack of cooling) just install it anyways and print a second cooler with the cooling running, this should make the second iteration look better.

description.text:
This is a cooler for delta printers. I designed this type of cooler since I thought most coolers where hard to fit to my own printer plus in most cases, they made it impossible to add other accessories such as auto calibration probes, etc.

This cooler consists of 3 parts. First the effector extender which is basically a ring that enables the user to add as many accessories as needed. Second, we have the adjusters. These were designes to regulate the height of the cooler, to fit any printer as well as as to enable the user to move the cooler in the horizontal plane to fit any custom needs. Finally the cooler itself, which provides a very nice tangential flow of air which means that the amount of air that touches the hot bed is minimal (minimising the risk of the printing part getting loose). This current of air will mostly cool the filament being extruded.

Just fit the mouth of the radial fan (which should have a size of 50x50x12) into the tip of the cooler and you should be good to go.

Parts Needed:

Effector Extender x1
Cooler Adjuster x4
Tangential Cooler x1
M3 Screws x 8
M3 Nuts x 6

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm Nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed with PLA @ 190C. I would recommend to first print it at a very low speed 20%, and then if the top of the cooler got bent a little (since it has no support underneath and lack of cooling) just install it anyways and print a second cooler with the cooling running, this should make the second iteration look better.
Designed with Catia R20.

description.text:
My Keurig 2.0 suffered from an issue with weak supports in the hinge of its mouth. The metal sliding support bar eventually broke through the plastic bridge that Keurig designed, and it kept getting stuck. I had to manually pull the bar over the broken bridge, until I decided that this merited a simple fix.

This design has a notch in it so the hinge has something to latch onto, as to not slide closed when it's in the open position.

Print these parts, and glue them into place with the notch facing the front of the machine.

description.text:
As a complement to this kit : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2492182 , those simple corner brackets add more vertical rigidity to the Tarantula.

The STL contains a single piece, print a set of 4, with a 30% infill and 1.2mm walls and top/bottom layers.

Each weighs around 17 grams, and requires 4 M4 bolt with 4 T-nuts.

They are to be placed above the original corner inserts, that have to be left in place.

Now with an additional STL that will let you channel the Y stepper and endstop cables
Easiest way is to place the cable slit on the top side, insert the cables along the X axis, then attach the bracket (loosely) on that side.
Then insert the cables along the Y axis and use hot glue to held them in place.
Finally push the bracket against the Y axis and tighten everything for good.

title: Customizable Helix (Helical) Antenna Frame and Winding Template
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
CAUTION: WORK IN PROGRESS

This thing is work in progress. It works good for me, but that does not mean I got every case. I will leave this as work in progress as long as I do not get 10 makes and some feedback.

You can help make this thing better, print it, build it, test it and tell me what you think, where you ran into problems what you liked, what you did not like. Also let me know if the instructions are not clear at any point.

The first time I tested this antenna I was blown away, and I hope I can share this experience with you!

About

This thing will generate an antenna "frame" and a winding template for your custom helix antenna. Helix antenna are easy to build, polarized, directional antennas with high gain.

The default settings will generate all parts for a right hand polarized, 5.8GHz, 5 turn Helix Antenna with ~10dBi gain, 1mm diameter antenna wire and a beam with of ~50 degrees, to be used for FPV.

More turns means higher gain, but also results in a narrower beam.

The use of a reflector is highly recommended and can be as easy as a copper PCB. either round or square. More information regarding reflectors may be found in this paper

The winding template changes depending on selected polarization. Depending on how you assemble the frame you can use it for the right or left hand polarized antenna.

Use this great calculator to get all the base values for your helix antenna. It will also show you the gain of your antenna and beam width.

The customizers default settings will generate a round reflector frame, you can check out my tool for cuttinig discs from square stock

Tools

For this project you will need the following tools:

  • Snips
  • Hobby knife
  • Soldering Iron & solder
  • Dremel / Rotary tool

Materials

Other than the 3D printed parts you will need the following materials:

  • Antenna Wire - I used 1mm diameter silver coated copper wire. Diameter is not that critical, and the material should be single core and you should be able to easily solder to it. * Reflector - I used Bungard double sided copper PCB's. Again, the material and thickness is not that important.
  • Coaxial Cable - again, does not matter too much, as long as it has an impedance of 50 Ohms. I tried it with the flexible RG58 but also with the semi rigid RG402 which in my opinion is the better choice for on goggle mounting.
  • Wave Trap - some solderable sheet of metal. I used copper tape and stacked multiple layers, again material should not matter too much, as long as it is not too thick (~0.5mm).
  • Heat Shrink - I like to color code my antennas, red heat shrink for right hand polarized and blue for left hand polarized.
  • SMA / RP SMA connector - depending on the receiver you are using you will need an appropriate SMA connector.

Preparation

If you do not use the same materials as I do, or want to use different specs, chances are, that you will need to change one or more parameters in the customizer. Give the customizer some time for rendering. The helix is quite complex to render, so it might take some time (took 30 minutes when I rendered the attached stl's from the default settings.)

Polarization

The polarization is only important for the winding template, all other parts may be used for both, left and right hand polarized antennas. Adjust the polarization value in the General Tab.

Frequency, Turns and Wire Diameter

If you intend to use a different frequency than 5.8GHz or a different number of turns than 5, head over to the calculator and fill in the following values in the General Tab of the customizer:

  • turns: Amount of turns
  • D: Inner Diameter of hte antenna
  • d: Outer Diameter of the antenna wire, adjust this for your printers tolerances
  • L: The length of the helix

Reflector Material and shape

In the Reflector Cover Tab, adjust reflectorThickness to the thickness of your reflector material. Adjust reflectorDiameter to at least the minimum diameter given by the calculator from above. A circle is recommended but square shape may also be used, if you are to lazy to go for a round shape ;-) Adjust reflectorShape accordingly.

Coaxial Cable

Again, in the Reflector Cover Tab, adjust coaxialDiameter to the thickness of your coaxial cable (with shielding, but without insulation).

Tolerances

Should your parts not fit well enough, check the Tolerances Tab and adjust values accordingly.

Parts

In the General Tab you will also find a dropdown with the parts to render. When rendering all parts it may take some time and the customizer might time out - because of the rather complicated winding template. I recommend reviewing with the Frame Parts selection.

Printing

The customizer will generate one file per part and one file with all the parts including winding template and another file with only the frame parts in case you already have your winding template.

Top and bottom frame part may be used for left and right hand polarized antennas, you only need to turn one of the pieces by 180 degrees before sliding it together.

I recommend printing the first layer rather slowly (20mm/s) to give the slopes of the frame a good chance of adhesion to the build plate.

Assembly

Step 1: Reflector

While the parts are printing you can already start by preparing the reflector. I decided to go with a round reflector with a diameter of 49mm, this is bigger than the recommended minimum diameter from the calculator and allows me to get 6 reflectors out of one PCB, without wasting too much material.

Mark the center of your reflector, also mark the hole for the coax cable (innerDiameter + wireDiameter) / 2. If you are going for a round reflector you can use my disc shaper tool drill a 2mm hole in the center and for the coax. Increase the hole for the coax until it fits snuggly, with the shielding but without the outer insulation.

Lengthen the coax cable, strip the shielding and inner insulation on one side about 5mm, stick it through the hole in your reflector and solder the shielding to the reflector. If you are using a double sided copper PCB as I do here, make sure to solder the shielding to both sides of the PCB.

Step 2: Winding the Antenna

Once your winding template has finished you can start winding the antenna. Stick the wire in the little hole on the bottom, and start winding the wire slowly around the template. Keep it as tight as possible. Once you are done, use your snips to cut away the bottom part and turn the antenna off the template. The antenna windings might compress back a bit so gently pull them apart.

Step 3: Antenna support

Assemble top and bottom part of the antenna support, make sure that all the holes are clear and you have enough space for the wire. Start turning the antenna through the holes, until you reach the bottom.

Step 4: Enclosure

slide the reflector into the groves of the antenna support, add the ring with the slits from the top and the cover from the back. At this point you can glue ring and cover shut.

Step 5: Soldering Antenna

Solder the Antenna wire to the core of the coaxial cable. Make sure that the first 1/4 loop is at a height of 2.5mm from the reflector to the center of the wire (Feed point height).
Cut the center pin of the coax to height.

Step 6: Wavetrap

Cut the wavetrap to size (6.5mm x 3.2mm for 5.8GHz or Length in cm = 3720 / f in MHz, Width in cm = 1860/f in MHz) and solder it to the the center of the first 1/4 turn of your antenna.

Step 6: SMA / RP SMA

Strip the shielding and inner insulation from the coax cable on the other side about 3mm. Solder the center pin to the inner core of your coax. If you want to use heat shrink put it on now. Plug in the coax with the center pin soldered to the plug. Solder the shielding to the plug and use hot air or your lighter to shrink the heat shrink.

Step 7: Cleanup

Should the wire of the antenna be longer than the top hole, simply snip it. As last check, make sure you did not short out the antenna anywhere, therefore simply check for continuity on the SMA Connector.

That is it, you now have build your own helical antenna, now got out, test it and let me know what you think.

Results

I first build the square version you can see in the images. I went out and tried it out and was blown away by the results, 750m with a transmitter on 25mW and a clover leaf antenna.

Massive penetration, having some trees in line of sight was no problem, also the image was crystal clear almost all the time.

Shout outs

Massive shout out to IBCrazy from RCGroups who came up with the wave trap and made the helix antenna popular for FPV.

References

RCGroups' IBCracy helical Antenna and Wavetrap Tutorial

title: Anycubic i3 Mega bed thumb screw caps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Thumbscrew caps for the i3 mega. These clip over the head of the brass thumbscrew and secure with a 3mm (or similar) self-tapping screw.

As the cap has 10 points and the pitch on the adjustment screws is 0.5mm, moving the cap by 1 point moves the bed by .05mm which makes it easy to make fine adjustment to the bed height.

There are two drive dogs on the side opposite the screw, and the screw pushes the thumbwheel over that way a little so that there's no risk of these slipping round.

My thumbscrews measure 14mm x 3.5mm

No

print_settings.Notes:: You can use any infill percentage, I just always tend to use 50% for my cookie cutters.

description.text:
Another re-mix of the Mickey Cookie Cutter by Platridi ...

I had a request for "Rainbow Mickeys" and although I knew I could decorate them free-hand, I felt more comfortable having the different color bands pre-defined for me so the decorating would be easier and ultimately look better.

This is the result, a Mickey Head Cookie Cutter with the seven (7) color bands pre-defined.

I have been asked to include the Sugar Cookie Recipe I use, so a copy will be included with the STL files when you download this design set.

title: iPhone 7 Plus / iPhone X camera mount

description.text:
This is an iPhone 7 Plus camera (stand) mount that holds the phone WITH the case on. I made two versions, one for Apple's own case and another for a slightly thinner case. It has modeled 1/4 inch ANSI threads, the same common ones that my Canon 7D has on the bottom.

I printed the part using ABS as it needs some flexibility. PLA may be too rigid and break. PETG should work also.

Here is a public link to the Fusion 360 design. It has the phone width and height (with case) as parameters. http://a360.co/2v6nZG9

This is a slight tweak to David Randolph's excellent 3mm hood and side panels:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23386
The only major change is that I extended the edges of the 45deg piece so there was less gap between where it meets with the top cut piece and the front cut piece.
It fits great and there is only just a tiny bit of sagging on the 45deg piece. David opted to have a gap between these pieces to help dissipate some of the heat.

If you want what I am using, I made the ponoko design public:
http://www.ponoko.com/design-your-own/products/makerbot-replicator-3mm-hood-and-side-windows-8153
These are the exact same files I used to cut the pieces you see in the pic. I have not updated the design to move the top right bolt on the right side window (when facing the front of the replicator) to the center. Some have reported the side bolt interfering with the gantry and extruder heads when homing them. I'm using these printable clips:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23636
And I haven't noticed a collision. I've uploaded an SVG file I created in illustrator. Let me know if it gives you trouble or you would like an alternative format. Update 6/23/2012 :
It turns out that both clips on the right side window are hitting the gantry or some component hanging off of it (like the wires). This is enough to prevent the gantry from easily homing.
For the time being, I've removed the two clips on the top of the right window. A piece of tape is holding the top in place until I can come up with an alternative. My next step is to shrink the thickness of the clips slightly. If this doesn't work, I'll probably update the plans and print a new window with the clip/screw hole in a different location. I'm not sure if the center of the window would provide obstruction, but it is better than the current positions.
